sn22.62:4.2: “Mendicants, there are these three ways of using language, terminology, and descriptions. They’re uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now, nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.
sn22.62:4.4: When form has passed, ceased, and perished, its term, label, and description is ‘was’.
sn22.62:7.1: consciousness has passed, ceased, and perished, its term, label, and description is ‘was’.
sn22.62:8.1: When form is not yet born, and has not yet appeared, its term, label, and description is ‘will be’.
sn22.62:11.1: consciousness is not yet born, and has not yet appeared, its term, label, and description is ‘will be’.
sn22.62:12.1: When form has been born, and has appeared, its term, label, and description is ‘is’.
sn22.62:15.1: consciousness has been born, and has appeared, its term, label, and description is ‘is’.
sn22.62:16.1: These are the three ways of using language, terminology, and descriptions. They’re uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now, nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.
sn22.62:16.2: Even those wanderers of the past, Vassa and Bhañña of Ukkalā, who taught the doctrines of no-cause, inaction, and nihilism, didn’t imagine that these four basic principles should be criticized or rejected.
sn22.62:16.4: For fear of being blamed, criticized, and faulted.”
